newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israeli minister says will visit China next week.
newsitem.headline: Israeli minister says will visit China next week.

text.p: Foreign Minister David Levy, who forged Israel's ties with China five years ago, said on Monday he would return to Beijing next week for an official visit.
"Next week I will visit Beijing," he told reporters after signing a customs agreement in Jerusalem with Chinese Vice-Premier Li Lanqing.
In January 1992 China, eager to play a Middle East peace role, became the last of the U.N. Security Council's five permanent members to establish ties with Israel.

Israel, which in the past had complained of Chinese arms sales to Arab states at war with it, received a promise from Li that China would do nothing to jeopardise the Jewish state's safety, Levy said.

"Today we received a guarantee that China will not do anything that could harm the security of the state of Israel or its interests. We are very satisfied from this important announcement," Levy said.

Israel Foreign Ministry spokesman Ygal Palmor said: "This is a cooperation-in-customs agreement. It is a document which establishes a framework for cooperation between the two offices responsible for customs."

He said this was the highest ranking visit of a Chinese official since October 1994. "The significance is quite clear. It reflects the level of economic cooperation between the two countries," Palmor said.
